name: Pro Cycling Manager 2014
description: Take on the role of manager and lead one of the pro cycling circuit's 75 teams. Join an outstanding 2014 season with more than 200 competitions across 550 stages including the prestigious Tour de France.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3/WINDOWS VISTA SP2/WINDOWS 7/WINDOWS 8 Processor: AMD/INTEL DUAL-CORE 2.2 GHZ Memory: 2048 MB RAM Graphics: 256 MB 100% DIRECTX 9 AND SHADERS 3.0 COMPATIBLE NVIDIA GEFORCE 7900/ATI RADEON X1600/INTEL HD 2000 Storage: 11 GB available space Sound Card: DIRECTX 9 COMPATIBLE Additional Notes: INTERNET CONNECTION REQUIRED FOR GAME ACTIVATION AND ONLINE GAMING
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3/WINDOWS VISTA SP2/WINDOWS 7/WINDOWS 8 Processor: AMD/INTEL DUAL-CORE 2.6 GHZ Memory: 2048 MB RAM Graphics: 512 MB 100% DIRECTX 9 AND SHADERS 3.0 COMPATIBLE NVIDIA GEFORCE 8600GT/ATI RADEON X1900 OR HIGHER Storage: 11 GB available space Sound Card: DIRECTX 9 COMPATIBLE Additional Notes: INTERNET CONNECTION REQUIRED FOR THE GAME ACTIVATION AND THE ONLINE GAMING

reviews.review_text: I haven't played this series since PCM 2009, while I hardly remember some of the features from PCM2009, I can say with confidence that PCM 2014 has a few items that can draw the player into the game - but there are other items that will draw you away. For one let's highlight the positive mechanics that I found in the game:  Beautiful graphics Relatively clean interface and menu Somewhat of a comprehensive tutorial Great in game commands R&D feature was a step in the right direction  Some negatives:  Cluttered inbox, you'll get mail from a bunch of miscellaneous events that don't impact or pretain to your current game which I would just simply classify as spam (Something minor which can be easily fixed by zero'ing off the 'announcer/commentator under sound options) But the announcer sounds cheesy as hell, I don't even think ESPN announcers sound that bad.  If you haven't played PCM before, the tutorial might not be enough to properly introduce the game to you. There are many screens on the UI (not as bad as football manager!), it wil take some time to get used to it all. A few minor graphical glitches during the race that don't impact the quality of the game (cars driving through the race formation, racers 'ghosting' through each other)  It's hard to say what exactly needs patching as of right now, my first race was fine and I didn't encounter anything wild that needs to be addressed immediately. I would recommend this game to someone who is interested in cycling or management of cycling teams. would buy again 10/10.
It's dated and the UI is not real glossy, but it still has an incredible feeling cycling stages around Europe and others.

Only for hardcore cycling fans. In general, I'm a fan of management games like Football Manager and OOTP Baseball. But this game doesn't make it easy to learn the game or the sport. The graphics look nice, I haven't had any crashes, there are loading screens but they aren't that slow, and the 3D races make it somewhat interesting. But... spending hours and hours racing in a sport and game I don't understand is not fun.
Unable to play the game as i cannot advance beyond the profile page. Still waiting for reply from steam support. will review if i get game to work. At the moment i would not recommend game.
Still trying to get to grips with the system but so far it is a good game will take lots of pratice

Update: After tuning down my graphic settings a bit, the game rarely crashes, and has actually become enjoyable. The season planning tools is a highlight in this years release, and is definatly something that makes this version a lot more enjoyable to play in comparison to older releases. Like most manager games, you'll need basic knowledge about the sport to really immerse yourself in the gaming experience, so I'd say that this game is still mostly for cycling enthusiasts. The AI is actually pretty realistic, like in real life, the Tour de France in my career had a pretty random outcome, since most of the favorites lost a lot of time on the cobblestone stage in Britain, was lucky to have my team captain in the front group, which ended up landing me a spot in the top 3.  The game as a whole looks better than last years installment. The UI is a lot more intuitive than in previous games of the series. The AI actually seems pretty well balanced, and it seems like computer controlled riders can also have a bad day, which can come in handy, especially in the stage races.
